author: warren_534
body:
Options on leveraged ETFs are just more costly, but relatively the same % of price as regular SPY, proportionally speaking.
You're better off buying multiple SPY options, due to far greater liquidity.

Leveraged ETFs are fine for short term moves, but suffer from beta slippage on longer time frames due to being rebalanced and recalculated daily.

You might consider a ZEBRA put strategy, which will profit from an index decline, as well as increasing volatility, with no worries about time decay. 

I have some put ZEBRAs on in ES and NQ futures options.

author: quiethandle
body:
I'd like to introduce you to the put zebra. Zebra stands for zero extrinsic back ratio. There are a bunch of videos about this on the tasty trade website.

You purchased two in the money 70 Delta puts, and you sell one just out of the money 40 Delta put. Tweak the exact strikes so that your extrinsic value you are paying for is basically zero. Your Delta will be close to -100.

It's expensive, but you don't suffer from theta decay. And you don't risk getting your account blown out by literally shorting stock.

author: rupert1920
body:
A table like this is good for simpler strategies like straddles and strangles, where the Greeks are consistent throughout the life of the position (within the profit zone anyways).

But if you get into something like a diagonal spread, you'll find that you can be short theta or long theta at various times of the position. Likewise, with a calendar spread, you are long vega, yet because shorter dated options have larger IV swings, it can act like short vega.

Another example is a call ZEBRA - for all strike ranges from the current stock price up, it acts like 100 shares of stock and you're neutral in theta. But under that price, you're short theta. Very similar in other ratio spreads or broken wing flies where if you have a stock near the max profit zone, you won't realize it until very close to expiration as the Greeks flip.

So it's complicated to say the least...

author: LocalRemoteComputer
body:
One can their own basket of stocks in a broker like Fidelity and make those kind of gains or losses as a whole.  It helps distribute the risk and gain.  There are sector investments and select-type sector investments... but then again it's a small part of the whole, and subset of the zebra herd.  If someone finds a few million of the needed chips in a warehouse all those gains go the other way.

I have a portion in something low-cost like FTEC and VGT but it's not been in for long.  So far so good.  There will be other moments of opportunity.

Overall some sectors do better than others then something shifts... if you bet on the herd as a whole you don't have to keep shifting money within the herd. 

(And I wish I had cash on hand to make buys on all those semiconductor companies, but I'm not that kind of trader.)

author: quiethandle
body:
I'd like to introduce you to the put zebra. Zebra stands for zero extrinsic back ratio. There are a bunch of videos about this on the tasty trade website.

You purchase two in the money 70 Delta puts, and you sell one just out of the money 40 Delta put. Tweak the exact strikes so that your extrinsic value you are paying for is basically zero. Your Delta will be close to -100.

It's expensive, but you don't suffer from theta decay. And you don't risk getting your account blown out by literally shorting stock.

You can reduce the cost of this by going shorter distance out in time. It's not necessary to do this a year out, because you didn't pay for any net extrinsic value.

For management, if the stock moves against you and goes to your long strike, theta will now be working against you big time, so you should close the position and re-establish with new strikes.

author: Ensemble_InABox
body:
I love ENPH. Won’t comment on your question but ENPH is the best play in the alternative energy space. Margins are top notch, product road map is top notch, C team are excellent, and the space is growing.

It got super richly valued at the start of the year because people thought climate change was a big priority for Biden.
